Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing clothing to expand inventory

loans.name: Yawo Agbesi

texts.en: Monsieur Yawo Agbesi D. is 35 years old and sells phone cards to recharge credits for cell phone use in Togo. He is married to another merchant and they have one child together. He sells cards for the three different cell phone companies in Togo - Togocel, Moov, and Illico - which allows him to serve as many customers as possible. He has been selling these cards for the past 4 years. Now he is requesting his second microloan from WAGES of 200,000 CFA francs (the ISO code for this currency is XOF) to purchase 55 more cards. He hopes to increase his income to better care for his young family.

loans.use: To purchase phone cards

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is a married woman with two children who both attend school. Her husband is a driver and he supports his family financially. She has been operating her business of selling kikoi (a cotton fabric worn as a wrap) and window curtains for the last four years, selling from door to door to her neighbors. 

Previously she was selling raw potatoes. With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) she wants to purchase a bundle of kikois. She faces the major challenge of high competition from her immediate neighbors also doing the same business. She hopes that someday she will open a retail shop and supply to a larger market.

Mwanaisha rents a house with electricity and piped water. She decided to join because of its good reputation from the society. Her monthly expenses are  school fees and electricity.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of kikoi's for sale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has been operating her charcoal business for the past thirteen years and sells from home to her neighboring community. She is happily married with five children who all attend school. Her husband is a contractor by profession and he contributes to his family's basic needs. Elizabeth lives in her own house with no electricity but with piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and vehicle maintenance and repair.

With this 40,000 KES loan, Elilzabeth wants to buy five sacks of charcoal. Additionally she operates a taxi business and pick-up van for light transport. Elizabeth faces the major challenge of high transportation costs. She hopes that someday she will register her own company and become a big supplier in the market. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in the community.

loans.use: To purchase five sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Agbessignalé

texts.en: Agbessignalé A., 46 years old, lives and works in Lomé, Togo. He is married to another merchant and they have 5 children. Monsieur A. recently purchased a mill he uses to process corn into cornmeal. This is a lucrative business that allows him to provide for his family because cornmeal is a very important staple of the Togolese diet. But mills are expensive and he is now requesting a second loan of 500,000 XOF to help pay off the cost of the mill.

loans.use: To pay for the purchase and installation of a mill to process corn

loans.name: Wilbroad

texts.en:
K. Wilbroad, 63 years old, has been operating a cattle farm in Kyeganywa, Ibanda, where he has been selling cows to the periodic markets in western Uganda. In this business, he deals directly with farmers to purchase their cattle and then rears them for some time until he finds a ready market where he supplies butchers, hotels and other customers.

His main disadvantages in running this business have been the unstable cattle market prices and low capital input. With hard work and efficient customer care skills, he has managed to keep his business going for over 25 years. In a month, he makes profits in the amount of 200,000 UGX. His future plans are to fully expand his transactions which he says will see him earn more revenue to pay for his children’s education and other family requirements. With this loan, he wants to purchase more cattle for his farm.

loans.use: Purchase more cattle for his farm

loans.name: Mwafua

texts.en: Mwafua is married with six children. Four of her children have finished school and two still attend school. She has been operating her vegetable stall and a retail shop for the past seven years and sells at retail to her neighboring community. With the Kshs 30,000 loan, she wants to start a pharmacy shop, purchase medicine for her pharmacy shop, 50kgs of rice, sugar and a sack of beans. She faces the challenge of seasonality. Mwafua lives at her own house with no electricity but with piped water. She hopes that someday she will build houses to rent. Her main reason for working with Yehu is because of its good reputation and to get a loan to start a business. She cites school fees as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase medicine for her pharmacy, rice, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Pay auto insurance expenses for his taxi

loans.name: Abla

texts.en:
Madame Abla M. is 63 years old and lives in Lomé, Togo, where she sells cakes made from wheat flour. She is a widow and she has three children. She has been selling these little cakes, which are very popular here in Lome, since 2002.

Now she is requesting her third loan from WAGES for 250,000 CFA in order to purchase more wheat flour and some aluminum bowls she uses to prepare the cakes.

loans.use: To purchase wheat flour and aluminum bowls

loans.name: Raimundo

texts.pt:
Raimundo M. nasceu no Distrito de Namarroi, província de Zambézia, Norte de Moçambique, é divorciado e pai de 9 filhos com idades compreendidas entre os 5 aos 27 anos, todos vão a escola. Fez a 10ªclasse não concluiu devido a problemas de saúde. Vive na casa própria com sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém para além da sua família.


Sai de Zambézia a procura de emprego, junta se com sua esposa que o abandona quando ele fica doente. Hoje é auxiliar da migração ha mais de 22 anos, aufere um salario de 2.120.00mt mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e com ajuda do seu negócio consegue poupar algum na sua conta bancaria.



Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o segundo empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com pretende comprar produtos (cigarros, colgate, sabão, massas e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. O empréstimo anterior foi de 7.000.00mt foi usado para compra de material de construção. Esta confiante que vai pagar cem nenhum problema e pedir um novo, para construção de um estabelecimento e deixar de ser vendedor ambulante.
texts.en:
Raimundo was born in the Namarroi District, Zambezia Province, North of Mozambique. He is divorced and the father of 9 children between 5 and 27 years old. All children go to school. He completed 10th grade but didn't finish school due to health issues. He lives in his own house with his family and doesn't support anyone other than his family. He left Zambezia looking for a job and moved in with his wife. She left him when he got sick. He has been a migration assistant for more then 22 years. He earns a salary of 2,120 meticais a month, which goes toward household expenses. With the help of his own business he manages to save some money in his bank account. He has never had loans with other banks. He became familiar with Hluvuku throught friends who are also clients of the institution. This loan, in the amount of 10,000 meticais, is his second. He intends to buy products (cigarettes, toothpaste, soap, pasta and others) in order to increase his inventory. His previous loan, in the amount of 7,000 meticais, was used to purchase construction material. He is confident he will not have issues paying back the loan and will request another to build his own shop and no longer be a street vendor.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory (cigarettes, toothpaste, soap, pasta and others)

loans.name: Rwashamaire Tailoring, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Hard work and determination have made N. Edger what he is today. This all began after abandoning his former teaching profession, which helped him raise the capital that he used to develop his tailoring business which he operates from Nkongoro Trading Centre in Ntungamo.

This seems to be fulfilling for him as he is in position to earn 200,000 UGX on a weekly basis. This has made the 29-year-old married father of two able to cater for his family's needs. He looks forward to achieving his dream of owning a big business in the area and buying himself a car in the future for easy transportation of his business materials. With this loan, he hopes to buy more stock of materials to make good clothing designs for his customers.

loans.use: to buy more stock of materials to make clothing

loans.name: Antonio Simao

texts.pt:
Antônio Simão C. nasceu na Província de Inhambane no Distrito de Vilanculos, sul de Moçambique casado e pai de 1 filha de 3 anos de idade. Fez a 7ª classe não concluiu devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta 2 irmãos que vivem com ele. 

Saiu de Vilanculos para o Distrito de Namaacha a procura de emprego. Iniciou sua actividade comercial ha mais de 7 anos, hoje é dono de um estabelecimento de venda de eletrodomésticos cita no Mercado Central de Namaacha. Conta com 1 empregado que auxilia no seu negócio e consegue um lucro de cerca de 6.500.00mt, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancaria. 


Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinhos também comerciantes. Este é o quinto empréstimo de António na Hluvuku e quarto com Kiva no valor de 20,000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (recargas de telemovel, eletrodomésticos e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os anteriores empréstimos foram de (5.000.00mt, 7.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt) também foram para a mesma finalidade.

 Esta confiante que mais uma vez vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto, e solicitar novos empréstimos.
texts.en:
Antônio Simão was born in the province of Inhambane in the District of Vilanculos in Southern Mozambique. He is married and the father of a 3 year-old daughter. He went to school until 7th grade but didn't finish due to the lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and also supports two siblings who live with him. He left Vilanculos to look for a job in the Namaacha District. He started his business more than 7 years ago. Today, he owns his own appliance store in Namaacha's Central Market. He has one employee who helps him with the business. He has an income of 6,500 meticais per month, which is used in household expenses and still saves some in his bank account. He has never had loans with other banks. He became familiar with Hluvuku through neighbors who are also salespeople. This is Antonio's fifth loan with Hluvuku and fourth with Kiva, in the amount of 20,000 meticais. He intends to purchase prepaid cell phone cards, appliances and others to increase his inventory. The previous loans were for 5,000, 7,000, 10,000 and 15,000 meticais. All were used for this same goal. He is confident he will once again pay the loan back ahead of schedule and request new loans.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory (prepaid cell phone cards, appliances and others)

loans.name: Kissao

texts.en: Monsieur Kissao A. is 41 years old and lives in Lome, Togo. He is married to a seamstress and is the father of two children. Since 1999, he's been the director of his own organization called "INTEL - Informatique et Telecom" where he offers Internet services, sells computers, and trains others in information technology. He has requested a loan from WAGES of 500,000 XOF in order to purchase another computer for his office. This will be his second loan from WAGES.

loans.use: To purchase a computer

loans.name: Zelia Ernesto

texts.pt:
Zélia Ernesto M., nasceu na província de Maputo no distrito de Namaacha, casada e mãe de 4 filhos de 2, 10, 11 e 12 anos, os três mais velhos vão a escola. Fez 8ą classe e não concluiu devido a falta de condições financeiras, neste momento faz ensino a distância. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta sua mãe enviando alguns bens alimentares.


Nunca saiu da sua terra natal, tem um negocio próprio de venda de produtos de primeira necessidade ha mais de 10 anos. Não possui nenhum empregado e consegue um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00mt, que aplica nas despesas de casa e com ajuda do marido que trabalha numa empresa de segurança, consegue poupar algum através de Xitque (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de suas amigas que também são clientes desta instituição. Este é o quarto empréstimo na Hluvuku e primeiro com kiva no valor de 20.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar produtos (folhas de chá, óleo, açúcar, farinha e outros) para aumentar a quantidade de seus produtos. Os empréstimos anteriores foram no valor de (15.500mt, 25.000.00mt e 31.000.00mt) foram usados para criação de pintos.

Esta confiante que vai pagar cem nenhum problema e pedir um novo empréstimo para aumentar no valor que terá colectado para compra de uma carrinha que facilitara os seus trabalhos diários.
texts.en:
Zélia Ernesto was born in the Namaacha District, in the Province of Maputo. She is married and the mother of 4 children who are 2, 10, 11 and 12 years old. The three oldest go to school. She completed 8th grade but didn't finish due to the lack of financial resources. Currently, she in enrolled in long distance learning. She lives in her own house with her family and supports her mother by sending her groceries. She has never left her hometown and has had her own business selling basic goods for more than 10 years. She does not have any employees. She has an income of around 6,000 meticais per month, which is used for household expenses. With the help of her husband who works in a security company she manages to save some through a traditional rotational savings system (Xitique). She has never had loans with other banks and became familiar with Hluvuku through friends who are also clients. This loan, in the amount of 20,000 meticais, is her fourth with Hluvuku and first with Kiva. She intends to buy tea leaves, cooking oil, sugar, flour and other products to increase her inventory. Her previous loans were for 15,500, 25,000 and 31,000 and were used to raise chicks. She is confident she will have no problems paying the loan back. She is also confident she will request a new loan to increase the amount she has saved to buy a cart to help with her daily work.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory (tea leaves, cooking oil, sugar, flour and others)

loans.name: Djima

texts.en: Monsieur Djima B., 32 years old, lives and works in his hometown of Lome, Togo. He has a general store called Ets. Mawusse, and has been in business since 2005. He is experienced in taking loans from WAGES and is now requesting his third loan of 500,000 XOF in order to purchase merchandise such as flour, canned goods, and other items, for his store .

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Mwanamgeni

texts.en: Mwanamgeni is married with five children. Four of the children attend school and one is too young for school. She has been selling charcoal for the past year. She sells from home to her neighboring community. With the Kshs 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase fruits and two sacks of charcoal. Her other source of income is selling soft drinks. Her husband also contributes to her income. The main challenge she faces is seasonality, especially during rainy seasons. She owns a house with electricity and piped water. Mwanamgeni hopes that someday she can open a charcoal stall and become a potential supplier. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation. She cites electricity and school fees as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To purchase fruit and charcoal.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en: Anita is a single woman with one child who attends school. She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. She has been selling cosmetics and women's undergarments at the market in her community. She also runs a retail shop, which contributes to her income. With the loan of Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase a bundle of clothes to sell. She faces a competitive environment, as many people in the neighborhood work in the same business. Anita hopes that someday she will open a boutique and increase her profits so she can live a comfortable life. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get a  loan to improve her living standards.

loans.use: To purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es:
Manuela es productora lechera y su esposo es Profesor Normalista quien trabaja en Achacachi. Su domicilio esta ubicado en la comunidad Irama Belén de la Provincia Omasuyos Achacachi. 

El préstamo lo destinará para la refacción de su establo de vacas.

Es primer crédito con Impro a través de Kiva. Por la actividad económica que Manuela realiza y por el análisis socioeconómico, el crédito es viable.
texts.en:
Manuela is a dairy farmer and her husband is an elementary school teacher in Achacachi. They live in the community of Irama Belén in the province of Omasuyos Achacachi. The loan will be used to renovate the cows’ stable. This is Manuela’s first loan with Kiva partner Impro. Because of the job that she does, and after a socioeconomic analysis, we have determined that Manuela qualifies for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to renovate cows' stable

loans.name: Ema

texts.es:
La señora Ema R. es soltera vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de Llojeta ladera oeste de la ciudad de La Paz.
La señora Ema R. es empleada domestica de una familia particular de esta ciudad ingresos con los que se mantiene.
El crédito solicitado es para la conclusión de construcción de una habitación en una fracción de terreno que le cedió su padre.
Esta es la tercera  ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Señora Ema R. is single and lives with her parents in the Llojeta area, on the hills west of the city of La Paz. She works as a maid for a family in the city and supports herself with the wages from this job. The loan she is seeking will be used to complete building a house on a plot of land left to her by her father. This is the third time that Ema has asked for a loan, and our analysis of her socioeconomic status qualifies her to receive one.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to complete house construction

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en: Zainabu is a happily married woman with two children who attend school. Her spouse is a driver by profession and he contributes to his family's basic needs. She owns a home with electricity and piped water. She cites electricity as her greatest monthly expense. She has been operating her soft drink business for the last two years. Recently she was employed as a receptionist. In addition, she has a poultry business and also has rental houses as another source of income. Zainabu sells from home to her neighbors and potential customers. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in the business. With the loan of Kshs 70,000, she wants to purchase a freezer for soft drink storage and chicks for her poultry business.  Her major goal is to have a poultry farm in the future. She decided to work with Yehu to get access to sustainable financial services.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer for soft drink storage and ten chicks for her poultry business.

loans.name: Fredisminda

texts.es:
Fredisminda tiene 53 años D. edad, resiD. en el Municipio D. Concepción Batres, departamento D. Usulután, es casada, viven son el esposo y dos hijos D. las edades D. 18 y 16 años, se dedica a la venta D. panes con pollo. 
Ella inicio el negocio gracias al apoyo D. una amiga quien le enseño a preparar los panes,trabaja siempre por las tardes, es una  persona emprendedora, solo que en ese momento no cuenta con el dinero suficiente para invertir en compra D. materia prima para continuar con su negocio, por lo cual solicita  un préstamo con el comprara: pollo, tomates, cebolla, lechuga, zanahoria, remolacha, especies para tener productos y aumentar las ventas.
Este dinero le permitirá contar con todo lo necesario para elaborar los panes, darle mejor servicio al cliente, las aspiraciones D. Fredisminda son ampliar el negocio, y mejorar la calidad D. vida D. la familia.
texts.en:
53-year old Fredisminda lives in the municipality of Concepción Batres, in the department of Usulután with her husband and their two children aged 18 and 16. Fredisminda started the business through the help of a friend who taught her how to make bread. She always works the afternoon shift. She is a hardworking person, but at the moment does not have enough money to buy the ingredients necessary for her business. So she is asking for a loan to buy chicken, tomatoes, onions, lettuce, carrots, beets so she can make different products and increase sales. The money will allow her to buy everything she needs to make these products and proviD. her customers with better service. Her hopes for the future incluD. expanding her business and improving her family’s quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy chicken, tomatoes, onions, lettuce, carrots, beets

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
Tomas tiene 28 años de edad, reside en el Municipio del Tránsito, Departamento de Usulután, es soltero no tiene hijos, y vive con el papa, la madre y dos hermanos de 17 y 9 años de edad se dedica a la venta de productos de medicina natural.
El negocio lo inicio gracias a la ayuda de un amigo, que también vende productos de medina natura, actualmente maneja solo el negocio no tiene un horario fijo, Tomas esta solicitando un préstamo para mejorar la vivienda, cambiar el techo, con el dinero el quiere comprar Laminas, cuartones de madera, clavos, alambre y otros materiales que son necesarios para el cambio de techo.
El préstamo permitirá mejorar la vivienda de Tomas, darle un lugar seguro donde viva la familia, los sueños de Tomas son tener una vivienda digna para vivir junto a su familia y continuar el negocio.
texts.en:
Tomas is 28 years old and lives in the town of Tránsito in the department of Usulután. He is single and has no children; he lives with his parents and his two brothers, 17 and 9 respectively. He works selling homeopathic medicine. He started his business thanks to help from a friend who also sells natural medicine products. Currently he runs his business alone and does not have a set schedule. Tomas is applying for a loan to improve his home by replacing the roof. He will use the money to purchase roofing materials, wood, nails, wire, and other materials. The loan will allow Tomas to improve his home and give his family a more secure place to live. Tomas' dream is to have proper housing for him and his family and to continue with his business.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of roofing materials

loans.name: Benkadi 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 1 est composé de femmes mariées du village de DANGASSO dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39  ans et au moins 7enfants.
Elles cultivent  du  fonio, de l’oseille et du gombo.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt de campagne.
FATOUMATA C. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants, au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
FATOUMATA C., compte réaliser, après l’écoulement des produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les  dépenses  courantes  de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of married women from the village of Dangasso in the San district, a region of Segou (the fourth administrative area of Mali). They live in traditional families. They are of an average age of 39 and have a minimum of 7 children each.They grow fonio, sorrel, and gombo. In the interest of improving the performance of their farms, the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan group 2 years ago. Having repaid the previous loans correctly they are requesting their second rural loan. Fatoumata C. intends to use her credit to buy a sufficient quantity of fonio seeds, small farming machinery, and farming supplies, such as seeds, fertiliser, and other products, at the market in San. After the winter period the harvest will be stored for a certain period of time to appreciate in value before being sold at the markets of San, Dah and the surrounding area, retail (often wholesale) for cash to customers who usually come from the large towns. Fatoumata C. hopes to make a profit of 35 000 FCFA after the sale of the products, which will be used for the repayment of the interests of the loan and for daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Barbara Belli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds,fertiliser and other products and small tools.

loans.name: Benkadi  2 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  2 est constitué de femmes mariées du village de DANGASSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 44  ans et au moins 9 enfants.
Elles cultivent  du  fonio, de l’oseille et du gombo.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt de campagne.
FANTA D. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, exclusivement  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 17.500 à 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 2 group is composed of married women from the Dangasso village in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 44 years old and have nine children. They cultivate fonio [a local sort of millet], sorrel and “gombo” [okra]. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program two years ago. After having duly repaid previous loans, they are now on their second agricultural loan. Fanta D. plans to use her loan to purchase a sufficient supply of fonio seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, specifically at the big market in San. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases, before being sold at the big markets of San, Dah, and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale) for cash to customers mostly coming from big towns. After selling their products, the group members expect to obtain an income from 17,500 to of 40,000 West African francs each, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanajuma is a divorced woman with seven children. All of her children have completed their O-levels. She owns a home with no electricity, but with piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.  She has been operating her food vendor business for the last two years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mwanajuma faces the challenge of competition from other food vendors in the market. With the loan of Kshs 40,000, she wants to purchase sand and blocks to finish construction of her rental houses. She hopes that someday she will run a wholesale charcoal business. She decided to work with Yehu because of its good reputation.

loans.use: To purchase sand and blocks to finish her ongoing construction of rental houses.

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es: Antonio, de 55 años es un padre de familia muy sencillo y alegre, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposa Sara de 53 años y sus tres menores hijos, a quienes desea brindarles un mejor futuro. El arduo trabajo que Antonio realiza en sus chacras, le ha traído como resultado una buena producción, ya que la papa, alverja, olluco y oca que sembró, han sido cosechadas abundantemente y con muy buena calidad. De esta manera disfruta del esfuerzo que le puso a sus campos agrícolas, aunque para lograr tener una excelente cosecha, debe siempre estar pendiente de sus plantaciones y procurar que la plaga afecte en su desarrollo. Con el tiempo espera comprar más tierras para aumentar su producción. Este es el quinto crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene que poner todo de su parte y trabajar muy duro para pagar puntualmente sus cuotas y esta dispuesto a hacerlo. En su grupo comunal es un socio muy responsable, motivo por el cual es muy respetado. Con los mil quinientos nuevos soles que solicita, comprará más abono para mejorar la productividad de sus chacras.
texts.en:
Antonio, 55 years old, is a simple and happy family man. He has a house where he lives with his 53-year old wife Sara and their three children, who they hope to provide with a better future. The hard work that Antonio puts in on his land has brought him good production. His crops of potatoes, peas, and oca, a South American tuber, have been ample and of good quality. So Antonio get to enjoy the fruits of his hard labor in the field. However, to have an excellent harvest one must always be vigilant and make sure that pests do not affect the plants' growth. With time Antonio hopes to buy more land to increase his production. This will be his fifth loan from MFP; he knows that he has to do his part and work hard to make his payments on time, and he is certain that he will do so. In his community group he is a well-respected partner. With the 1,500 new soles from the loan he will buy more fertilizer to improve the productivity of his lands.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer

loans.name: Benkadi  3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 3 est composé de femmes mariées du village de DANGASSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 41  ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles cultivent  du  fonio, de l’oseille et du gombo.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé les prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt de campagne.
SANATA D., est des membres du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, exclusivement  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN, DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice 21000 à 39500CFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courant de la famille.
texts.en:
he Benkadi 3 group is composed of married women from the Dangasso village in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 41 years old and have at least six children. They cultivate fonio [a local sort of millet], sorrel and “gombo” [okra]. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program two years ago. After having duly repaid previous loans, they are now on their second agricultural loan. Sanata D. plans to use her loan to purchase a sufficient supply of fonio seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, specifically at the big market in San. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases before being sold at the big markets of San, Dah, and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale too) for cash to customers mostly coming from big towns. After selling their produce, each group member expects to obtain an income between 21,000 and 39,500 West African francs, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Maria Imelda

texts.es:
María tiene 37 años D. edad, resiD. en Cantón Amate, del Municipio D. Santa Elena, departamento D. Usulután, es casada, vive con el esposo y tres hijos D. las edades D. 13,7 y 5 años respectivamente. Posee una tienda D. productos básicos, se Llama Tienda Sagrado Corazón D. Jesús.
El negocio fue por iniciativa propia, trabaja junto son el esposo y la hija mayor, no tiene horario fijo, son una familia trabajadora y actualmente está solicitando un préstamo para invertir en productos para tienda, como son aceite, arroz, frijoles, Harina D. Maíz, y otros que le demandan los clientes con estos ayudara a incrementar las ventas ya que tendrán más mercadería, la dificultad que presentaría seria que las ventas no fueran positivas.
Los sueños D. María son ver dos negocios grandes que le permitan darle una vida desente a la familia, apoyar a los hijos con los estudios, para que estos tengan un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
María is 37 years old and lives in Cantón Amate a village in the municipality of Santa Elena in the Usulután department. She is married and lives with her husband and her children, 13, 7, and 5 respectively. She has a small general store named The Sacred Heart of Jesus Store. She started the store herself; she works alongsiD. her husband and their eldest daughter. They don't have set hours at the store. They are a hardworking family and they are currently applying for a loan to invest in products for their store like oil, rice, beans, cornmeal, and other products their clients want. With more inventory sales will increase. The only risk is if sales are not good. María's dream is to have two larger businesses that will allow her to give her family a decent life and support her children's education so that they can have a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of oil, rice, bean, cornmeal, and other products

loans.name: Benkadi  4 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 4 est composé de femmes mariées du village de DANGASSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 36  ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  du  fonio, de l’oseille et du gombo.  
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  les  prêts précédents, elles sont à leur deuxième  prêt de campagne.
SATOU C. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence de fonio, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de SAN. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes  sont  stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de SAN,  DAH et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Tandis que SATOU C. espère avoir 40.000FCFA, certains membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 22000à 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi 4 group is made up of married women from the village of Dangasso in the San district which is in the Segou area (the fourth administrative province of Mali).They live in traditional families. They are on average 36 years old and have at least 5 children each.They cultivate fonio, sorrel, and gombo. Hoping to optimise the production of their farms,the members of the group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso group 2 years ago. Having repaid the previous loans correctly, they are requesting their second rural loan. Satou C. intends to use her credit to buy an adequate amount of fonio seeds, small farm machinery and fertiliser and other products at the market at San. After the winter period the crop is stored for a period of time in order to appreciate in value before being sold retail (often wholesale) at the grand market at San, at Dah and at other local markets for cash to customers usually from the large towns. Whereas Satou C. hopes to make 40.000FCFA, some members of the group expect to make a profit of 22000 to 30.000 FCFA each after the sale of their farm products which will be used to repay the interest of the loan and daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Barbara Belli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds,fertiliser and other farming products and small  agricultural equipment.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.es: Rosalinda, de 32 años, vive en su casa que es propia en compañía de su esposo y sus 3 hijos.Desde hace 4 años, se dedica a la fabricación de tejas y ladrillos (para los techos)  de los terrenos que ella y su esposo arriendan. La materia  prima básica en la fabricación, es la tierra arcillosa, y también se abastece de materiales indispensables como arena, aserrín, ramadas y el pago de personal, además  la jornada  de su trabajo se prolonga durante todo  el día. Le gusta trabajar horas extras para aumentar su producción, y dice que las mejores épocas de rentabilidad  del negocio es durante el verano; y cuando  bajan las ventas es en invierno, por la dificultad que se tiene de adquirir los materiales de la fabricación,  y también porque no secan los ladrillos por las frecuentes lluvias de la zona por donde vive. Tiene planes de incrementar la extensión de su fábrica  para obtener una mayor producción, y así espera seguir adelante.Es el quinto crédito que tiene con MFP, y esta muy contenta de  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su banco comunal, porque  todos los  integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, además agradece  a todas las  personas que hicieron posible el  préstamo porque  le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio.Rosalinda tiene planeado invertir el dinero del  crédito en la compra de  aserrín y ramadas en grandes cantidades, para cumplir con todos los pedidos que tiene pendientes, y de esta manera espera incrementar la productividad de su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosalinda, 32 years old, lives with her husband and three children. Four years ago she started working making roof tiles and bricks (for roofs) from the land that she and her husband rent. The materials used in this process are the clay from the land along with materials that they buy like sand and sawdust. The work hours are long often lasting the entire day. She likes to work extra hours to increase production and she says that the most profitable times for this business is the summer. Sales are slower during the winter because it is more difficult to gather the necessary materials for production and because the bricks will not dry due to frequent rains. She has plans to expand her factory to increase production and thus improve their situation in life. This is her fifth loan with MFP and she is very happy to know that she has financial support because she has always been responsible with her payments. She is also happy to be part of the community bank because all of the members are responsible businessmen and women. Rosalinda plans to invest the money from the loan to purchase sawdust and wood in large quantities in order to fill all of her pending orders thus increasing her business' productivity.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of materials for making bricks and roof tiles

loans.name: Benkadi  1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  I  fait partie de l’association des femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 36  ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
HAWA S. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, exclusivement  au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, la récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de TENE,  de MOPTI  et dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
HAWA S. compte réaliser, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 40.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi I group is part of the married women’s association of the Sesso village in the San prefecture, in the Segou Region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The women live in traditional families. They are on the average 36 years old and have five children. Their main business is growing peanuts. In order to make their agricultural work profitable, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, and are now on their first agricultural loan. Hawa S. plans to use her loan to purchase a sufficient supply of peanut seeds, small tools and agricultural inputs, specifically at the big market in Tene. After the winter season, the harvest is stored for a while as its price increases, before being sold at the big market of Tene, the market of Mopti and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale) for cash to customers mostly coming from big towns. After selling her products, Hawa S. plans to earn an income, of 40,000 West African francs, which will be used to pay off the loan interest and cover ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing agricultural inputs, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Zena

texts.en: Zena is a widowed woman with four children, between the ages of 24 and 35, and two grandchildren. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She used to sell potatoes along the roadside to passersby. With the 40,000 Kshs loan, she hopes to purchase a load of firewood. She has been in the firewood sale business for three years and supplies firewood at a wholesale price to small entrepreneurs. She also gets some support from her children. She decided to work with Yehu because she wanted to uplift her family life.

loans.use: To purchase a load of firewood.

loans.name: Benkadi  2 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 49   ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent essentiellement de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
AISSATA SEYDOU D., qui est la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, la récolte est stockée pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elle ait de la valeur avant d’être vendue  au grand marché de TENE, de MOPTI et dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 15000 à 36000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 2 is a grouping of married women in the village of SESSO in the prefecture of San, which lies in the region of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women live in traditional families, average 49 years of age and have an average of at least five children each. They cultivate primarily peanuts. Since they are concerned with making their agricultural operations profitable, the group's members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and are on their first farming loan. Aissata Seydou D., who is the president of the group, is planning on using her loan to buy a sufficient quantity of peanut grains, as well as small equipment and agricultural inputs, at the large market in Tene. After the winter the crop is stocked for a certain amount of time in order to gain value before being sold at the large market in Tene, Mopti and surrounding markets, on a retail basis (and often on a wholesale basis) for cash to a customer base originating primarily from large towns. The group members are expecting to make a profit of 15,000 to 36,000FCFA, following the sale of their agricultural products; this will be used to repay the interest on the loan and to cover the daily family expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants, grains and small equipment

loans.name: La Buena Fe Group

texts.en:
Melida is the coordinator of her group. La Buena Fe 1 & 2 (The Good faith). She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long term-partner and a child. Melida is excited to be taking her 4th loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business by buying chickens, vegetables, and fruit to sell in her little fruit and vegetables stand. She will use the profits to invest in her business and in the future she wants to build a house. In the meantime she plans to continue enjoying to be with her baby.

Melinda's story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti). Her group is located in the rural area of El Seibo, an agricultural area. Like nearly all impoverished areas of the Dominican Republic, it suffers from unreliable running water (none of which is potable) and electricity .

loans.use: to buy fruit, vegetables and chickens

loans.name: Benkadi  3 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 3 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 28 ans et au moins 3 enfants.
Elles cultivent de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, cette année et sont à leur  premier prêt de campagne.
OUMOU B. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide   des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de TENE, de MOPTI et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 12500 à 37500FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 3 is a group of married women from the village of SESSO in the SAN prefecture of SEGOU (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 28 years old and have at least 3 children. They grow peanuts. With the intention of making their farming activities more profitable, the members of the group decided ton join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program this year. This is their first farming loan. OUMOU B. plans to use her loan to purchase a large enough quantity of peanut seeds, small tools and fertilizers at the general market of TENE. After the rainy season, the harvest is stored for a while for its value to increase, before selling it at the general markets of TENE, MOPTI and other nearby markets, retail (often wholesale), for cash to customers who mostly come from large towns. Each member of the group expects to make a profit on the sale of their agricultural products ranging from 12,500 to 37,500 CFA francs, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan and ongoing family expenses.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, seeds and small tools

loans.name: Benkadi  4 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 4 est un regroupement  de femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 33 ans et  5 enfants.
Elles cultivent de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leur premier prêt  de campagne.
YARA S. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide   des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, exclusivement  au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de TENE, MOPTI et dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 16000 à 28000FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 4 is a group of married women from the village of Sesso, in San prefecture, Segou region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and average 33 years of age and five children each. The women grow peanuts. Concerned about making their farm operations more profitable, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso this year and are now on their first farm loan. Yara S. intends to use her loan for buying a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, sundry equipment, and some farm supplies exclusively at the big market of Tene. After the winter, the harvests are stored for a while, so that they gain in value before being sold at the big market of Tene, in Mopti, and at surrounding markets. The goods are purchased with cash at the retail level (often in bulk) by customers generally from large cities. After their produce is sold, the group members each plan on making a profit of 16,000 francs CFA that will be use for repaying the loan interest and for covering common family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying supplies, seed, and sundry farming items

loans.name: Mayra Janeth

texts.es:
Mayra de 40 años, vive en el Paraíso de Guayaquil (zona periurbana, con aminos de tierra y lomas en disolución), ella tiene una pequeña Papelería en su casa, vende bisutera, cuadernos, plumas con la ayuda de sus hijas. 

Mayra es madre soltera desde hace años, para poder solventar su hogar tuvo que invertir sus ahorros y comenzar a vender bisutería en su casa de caña, poco a poco con esfuerzo pudo vender papelería, trabaja desde las 09h00am todos los días. Para poder tener mas ingresos necesita comprar con el préstamo aretes y pulseras y una vitrina.

En el futuro quiere que sus hijos tengan mas fuentes de ingresos con la papelería que ella quiere tener.
texts.en:
Mayra, 40 years old, lives in Paraíso de Guayaquil (an area on the outskirts of the city with dirt roads and eroding hills). She has a small stationery store that she runs out of her home. She sells beads, notebooks, and pens with the help of her daughters. Mayra has been a single mother for many years and to provide for her family she invested her savings and started to sell beadwork from her house made of sugar cane. Little by little she has been able to sell her products; she works from 9:00 AM every day. She will use the loan to purchase earrings, bracelets, and a display case. These products should help her increase her income. In the future she hopes that her children have a source of income with the stationery store that she hopes to have.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of earrings, bracelets

loans.name: Benkadi  5 Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi 5 est composé  de femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne  34 ans,  6 enfants et  cultivent de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. Elles sont à leur  premier prêt de campagne.
DJENEBA T., la présidente du groupe,  compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide,  des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles, au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de TENE, MOPTI et dans les marchés environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 15000 à 38.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 5 consists of married women from the village of Sesso in the prefecture of San, Segou region (Mali's Fourth Administrative District). They live in traditional families. On average, each is 34 and has six children. They are peanut farmers. Hoping to make more profit from farming, the group decided to sign up with Soro Yiriwaso this year, and are receiving their first operational loan. Djeneba T., the group's president, plans to use her loan to buy seed peanuts, small tools, and fertilizer. After the rains end, the harvest is stored long enough to increase in value and be sold in the big market of Tene Mopti and in nearby markets at retail (often, wholesale) to customers who mostly come from large towns. Each member of the group is counting on making a profit of between 15,000 and 38,000 CFA after their produce is sold. They will use the money to pay loan interest and day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seed and small tools

loans.name: Kpandjapou Marie

texts.en: Madame Kpandjapou Marie M. is 46 years old. She is single but takes care of her one child.  She lives in Lome, Togo where she has a bar called Buvette Marie. Marie is a very experienced entrepreneur, having had her bar since 1990. In order to increase her offerings and her profits, Marie has requested a loan of 500,000 CFA to purchase more drinks to sell. Hopefully the loan will allow her more working capital to invest in this well-established business.

loans.use: To purchase drinks for her bar

loans.name: Oscar Mauricio

texts.es: Oscar M. vive en Bogotá, tiene cuatro hijos en las edades de 5 a 24 años , desde hace un año Oscar y su socio emprendieron un negocio  muy creativo, es una   alternativa diferente,  para emprender un negocio donde empacan almendras, grageas y dulces en pitillo, organizados en cajas de 50 unidades. Juntos asumieron el reto de dar inicio a ese gran sueño de tener un negocio  a raíz de dificultades  en el ingreso, por eso desde hace un año y hasta ahora, están funcionando con mucho empeño, esfuerzo y trabajo para salir adelante; este es su primer crédito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y están requiriéndolo para comprar su materia prima como lo es, las  almendras, pitillos, silicona y stikers con los que lo marcan. Su sueño es comprar una vivienda para generar bienestar a su familia y que este negocio continúe creciendo. Ahora tienen un gran desafío y es precisamente la tramitología de la legalización, ficha técnica, etc. que se requiere, especialmente en lo relacionado  con el registro ante el INVIMA, organización de vigilancia y control y seguramente muy pronto   recibirán asesoría para hacerlo.
texts.en:
Oscar M. lives in Bogotá, and has four children between the ages of 5 and 24. In the past year, Oscar and his partner have started a very unique business where they pack almonds, small candies, and candy in straws into boxes comprised of 50 units. They decided to take on the challenge of embarking on this grand dream to have a business together due to financial difficulties. As a result, they have been working with great determination and effort to get ahead for one year. This is their first loan with the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, and they are in need of capital in order to buy goods such as almonds, straws and the stickers that they use for labeling. His dreams include buying a home for his family, and to see his business grow. Right now he has a huge challenge in dealing with bureaucratic red tape, particularly with the paperwork related to registering with INVIMA. This is the government agency responsible for regulating food safety standards and, surely, he will receive his approvals soon.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase items such as almonds, straws, and labels.

loans.name: Kokoe Hemefa

texts.en: Madame Kokoe Hemefa M. is 32 years old and works in Lome, Togo. She sells used clothing in Lome's largest outdoor market. She is experienced in this sort of business and has been working in it for about 10 years. She is married to a sound technician and they have two children. Madame M. is requesting a loan from WAGES of 300,000 CFA. This will allow her to purchase better and more diverse merchandise to satisfy her customers and increase her profits.

loans.use: To purchase two large bags of used clothing

loans.name: Benkadi  6 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi  6 est constitué de femmes mariées du village de SESSO dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 29  ans,  5 enfants et  cultivent de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et  sont à leur  premier prêt  de campagne.
BACO T. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants agricoles,  au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de TENE, MOPTI et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 15000 à 38000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi 6 consists of married women from the village of Sesso in the prefecture of San, Segou region (Mali's Fourth Administrative District). They live in traditional families. On average, each is 29 and has five children. They are peanut farmers. Hoping to make more profit from farming, the group decided to sign up with Soro Yiriwaso this year, and are receiving their first operational loan. Baco D. plans to use her loan to buy seed peanuts, small tools, and fertilizer at the big market in Tene. After the rains end, the harvest is stored long enough to increase in value and be sold in the big markets of Tene, Mopti and other nearby markets at retail (often, wholesale) to customers who mostly come from large towns. Each member of the group is counting on making a profit of between 15,000 and 38,000 CFA after their produce is sold. They will use the money to pay loan interest and day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seed and small tools

loans.name: Amematusia

texts.en: Madame Amematusia S. is 28 years old and lives in Lome, Togo. She has a small store in the Avedji neighborhood of Lome where she sells all sorts of different products, including drinks, cereals, phone cards, and other grocery items. She is married to a man in the military and they have two children. Madame S. has had her store since 2005 and is requesting her first loan from WAGES of 200,000 CFA. She'll use the loan to purchase four sacks of corn, 30 bags of Pure Water to sell, and phone cards.

loans.use: To purchase corn, water, phone cards, and other items

loans.name: Maria Otilia

texts.es:
la sra. Maria S. tiene 66 años de edad y es viuda, vive en la colonia Flor del Campo de la ciudad Capital.
Maria se dedica a lavado de ropa, de esta actividad se sostiene, lo hace 3 veces por semana.
tambien recibe un dinero de una pension del Instituto Hodureño de Seguridad Social por la muerte de su esposo.
Maria utilizara el credito para hacerle una mejora a su casa. 
Maria es una mujer responsable, sociable y es muy querida por sus vecinas. 
dice sentirse feliz ya que va contruyendo su casa poco a poco y la esta dejando como ella quiere.
texts.en:
Maria S. is 66 years old and is a widow. She lives in the Flor del Campo neighborhood of Tegucigalpa. Maria works washing clothing and supports herself with this work, which she does 3 days a week. She also receives a small pension from the Honduran Social Security Institute because of her husband's death. Maria will use this loan to make improvements to her home. She is a responsible and outgoing person and is well liked by her neighbors. She says that she feels happy and is building her house bit by bit in order to have everything as she wants it.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Fountain, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cement, bricks, sand and flooring

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase of corn, firewood, lime, water and matches.

loans.name: Tiessiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe TIESSIRI 1 est constitué de femmes mariées du village de N’TION dans  la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 38   ans, 4 enfants et  cultivent de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
NACENE  D.   compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants, au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de TENE, MOPTI  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 24500 à 39000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Tiessiri 1 group consists of married women from the village of N'tion in the prefecture of San, Segou region (Mali's Fourth Administrative District). They live in traditional families. On average, each is 38 and has four children. They are peanut farmers. Hoping to make more profit from farming, the group decided to sign up with Soro Yiriwaso this year, and are receiving their first operational loan. Nacene D. plans to use her loan to buy seed peanuts, small tools, and fertilizer at the big market in Tene. After the rains end, the harvest is stored long enough to increase in value and be sold in the big market of Tene, Mopti and in nearby markets at retail (often, wholesale) to customers who mostly come from large towns. Each member of the group is counting on making a profit of between 24,500 and 39,000 CFA after their produce is sold. They will use the money to pay loan interest and day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seed and small tools

loans.name: Bacilio

texts.es: Bacilio, de 51 años, es un padre de familia muy alegre y trabajador, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposa Bertha de 35 años y sus 3 queridos hijos, a quienes desea brindarles una mejor vida. Trabajando todos los días arduamente en sus cultivos, Bacilio trata de cambiar la vida que actualmente lleva, junto a su esposa siembran semestralmente papa, maíz y alverja, los cuales venden en el mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Tarma, ya que es ahí donde mejores precios obtienen. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cuidar sus siembras de las plagas. Lleva 40 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus cultivos, ya que los sacos que lleva son muy pesados. En adelante espera mejorar la calidad de sus productos y así obtener mejores precios. Este es el sexto crédito con MFP, siente que este crédito le será muy beneficioso en su crecimiento como agricultor. En su grupo comunal es un socio muy participativo y solidario. Con los dos mil quinientos nuevos soles que solicita, comprará más abono para sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Bacilio is a very happy and hard working 51- year old family man. He lives in his own house with his 35- year old wife, Bertha, and their three dear children, to whom they want to offer a better life. By working arduously every day with his crops, Bacilio is trying to change the life he currently leads. Together with his wife, he plants potatoes, corn and peas every six months. They sell their crop at the wholesale market in the city of Tarma, where they get the best prices. What he likes most about his work is keeping his plants safe from pests. He has been farming for 40 years and considers transporting his produce to be the most difficult part of his work because the bags he has to carry are very heavy. In the future, he hopes to improve the quality of his produce and thereby get better prices. This is his sixth loan with MFP. He feels that this loan will greatly benefit him in his growth as a farmer. He is a very participatory and supportive member of his communal bank. With the two-thousand nine-hundred PEN he is requesting, he will purchase more fertilizer for his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Marni Siegal, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase better fertilizer for his crops.

loans.name: Humberto

texts.es:
En un barrio muy cerca al  cumbiodromo de Barranquilla, donde se vive en época carnavalera una gran fiesta, vive el señor Humberto Pabón, hombre muy trabajador y tan conocedor de negocio que ha logrado a través de esta actividad tener 2 casas. A sus 74 años tiene 14 hijos en las edades de 18 y 44 años y se dedica al alquiler de lavadoras, negocio producto de su capacidad emprendedora de hace mucho, cuando en el año 1972 inició vendiendo mercancías en Maicao, municipio del departamento de la Guajira, al norte de Colombia. En ese entonces tenía una colmena en el centro, pero la suspendió porque fue afectado por la devaluación del Bolívar, moneda del país fronterizo de Venezuela. Como  en este negocio perdió gran parte del capital,  persistiendo puso un restaurante en el puesto donde vendía mercancía y ahí duró 3 años, pero como no colmó sus expectativas, se trasladó  a Barranquilla, iniciando el servicio de alquiler de lavadoras, al principio solo tenía 2 máquinas de lavar que puso al servicio de la comunidad y   se extendió   a más de 5 barrios cercanos.  Es asì como Humberto suele trasladar sus lavadoras él mismo en  una carretilla, a quien le solicita el servicio   y lo hace con gran cuidado,  por eso  las preserva en buen estado; igualmente como es muy organizado  y responsable con sus clientes, su actividad fluye constantemente. Tiene 16 clientes fijos y este servicio es su única fuente de ingresos; él  dice que su negocio ha sido una gran bendición para él,  ya que puede solventar todos los gastos y vivir cómodamente porque ha podido mejorar sus viviendas. Él es un hombre trabajador y honrado, goza de una gran aceptación con sus clientes en los diferentes barrios, donde ofrece sus servicios y ha sido muy puntual en el pago  de su anterior crédito. Hoy en día está solicitando a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo su segundo crédito por valor de $1.500.000 COP, con este financiamiento va a comprar 4 lavadoras más,  porque las que tiene no son suficientes, especialmente en los fines de semana, cuando las amas de casa se encuentran en su día de descanso laboral y se dedican a este quehacer, dejado de cumplir en  los días hábiles.
A través de su primer crédito  logró adicionar  más máquinas y gradualmente incrementar su ingreso. Sus metas es tener un capital disponible, adicional, para incluir en su negocio la venta de mercancías, actividad en la que tiene experiencia y aprovecharía el potencial de las amas de casa, que serian su principal nicho de mercado,  para este nuevo negocio
texts.en:
In a neighborhood very close to the industrial area of Barranquilla, where there is a great festival in the period of Carnaval, lives Señor Humberto Pabón. Humberto is a very hard working man who is such a business expert that he has been able, through his business activities, to acquire 2 houses. At his 74 years, he has 14 children between the ages of 18 and 44. Humberto makes his living renting washing machines. His business is a product of his long-time enterprising capacity that began in the year 1972 when he starting selling merchandise in Maicao, a town in the Department of Guajira, in the north of Colombia. At that time, he had a shop in a mall. He closed it when it was affected by the devaluation of the Bolívar, the currency of his country, which borders Venezuela. Because he lost a good part of his capital with that initial business, he persisted in opening a restaurant in the location where he had sold merchandise. It lasted 3 years. But since he didn't fulfill his expectations, he moved to Barranquilla and started his washing machine rental service. In the beginning, he had only 2 washing machines to offer as rentals in the community, but he expanded to serve more than 5 nearby neighborhoods. Humberto tends to bring his machines to whomever requests his service by himself in a hand truck. He transfers them very carefully, which is why they are still in good condition. Likewise, because he is very organized and responsible with his customers, his business constantly flows. He has 16 regular customers. Offering this service is his only source of income. He says that his business has been a great blessing for him since it allows him to clear all his expenses and to live comfortably in his improved his dwellings. He is a hardworking and honest man. He enjoys great success with his customers from the different neighborhoods where he offers his services. He was punctual with the re-payment of his previous loan. He is currently requesting a second loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo in the amount of $1.500.000 COP ($800 USD). With this financing he is going to purchase 4 more washing machines. The ones he has are insufficient to meet the demand, especially on the weekends when housewives have their day off and spend their time taking care of this chore, which is left undone from their work days. Through his first loan, he was able to add more machines and gradually increase his earnings. His goal is to have additional capital available to him so that he can start selling merchandise again. This is an activity in which he has experience, and he would use the housewives he currently rents to as his main niche market for this new business.

Translated from Spanish by Marni Siegal, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 4 washing machines in order to increase his weekend rentals.

loans.name: Tiessiri  2 Group
