CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen H. is 28 years old. He is married and has a son. Karen lives in Gandzakar village, Ijevan area and works at the State Labor Agency as a specialist. He is also engaged in animal husbandry. Also, Karen and his brother run a woodworking shop. Thanks to income from these occupations Karen supports his young family.

Now Karen is asking for a 1,000,000 AMD loan to buy five pigs and fodder for his farm's cows, calves and pigs.

loans.use: To buy five pigs and fodder for his farm's cows, calves and pigs.

loans.name: Ababana Group

texts.fr:
Mukankubana Edith est une femme de 30 ans, née à Kibungo, province du nord du Rwanda. Elle est mariée, elle a deux  enfants le plus âgée a 9 ans et le second a 6 ans, les deux  enfants vont  à l’école. Edith avec sa famille habite à Kigali, son niveau d’étude est 6 ème secondaire.

Elle fait le commerce de salon de coiffure pour dame, elle a une expérience de 4 ans dans ce domaine et les épargnes lui ont aidé de payer son loyer. Elle épargne dans ACB avec laquelle elle est client, il y a 3ans. Le prêt qu’elle vient de contracter c’est pour acheter des casques pour sécher les cheveux des femmes en salon de coiffure après le de frisage et en tirer les bénéfices et rembourser son prêt. 

Elle contracte son  premier prêt car son groupe est récemment formé, les intérêts  tirés de son business, elle les utilisera pour payer le loyer  et augmenter son chiffre d’affaires  et épargner.

Dans l’avenir, après avoir terminé de rembourser le prêt, elle pourra avoir un nouveau prêt, et elle pourra construire sa propre maison.
texts.en:
Edith Mukankubana is a 30-year old woman, born in Kibungo, a province in the Norht of Rwanda. She is married and has two children, the older of whom is nine years old and the younger six years old; both children go to school. Edith lives with her family in Kigali. Her level of formal education is junior high school. Her line of business is a hair salon for women. She has four years of experience in this business; her savings have allowed her to pay the rent. She has been saving with ACB [Amasezerano Community Banking] for three years. The loan she just took out is for purchasing salon hair dryers to be used after doing her clients’ hair; this will allow her to earn an income and repay her loan. She is on her first loan as her group has been recently formed; she will use the income derived from her income to pay for rent and to increase her business volume as well as savings. In the future, after repaying this loan, she could apply for a new loan and have her own house built.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing hair salon dryers

loans.name: Keo

texts.en: Mrs. Keo S. is a 51-year-old married woman and local villager living in a medium-sized home with family members in Kompong Cham Province. She owns a piece of farmland that she inherited many years ago from her grandparents. She and her husband use this land to grow different kinds of crops, including potatoes and rice. In the past, Keo S. hired a taxi to pick up her mature crop and take it to the market for sale or to anywhere else. Right now, she desires to own a vehicle to provide transportation for her family. However, Keo S. can’t save adequate cash to buy one. Therefore, she has decided to borrow a loan through Kiva’s field partner, HKL, in order to meet her purpose, above.

loans.use: To buy a vehicle to provide transportation.

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en: Samvel V. started his used car parts business in 1995. He is married and has two children. The family lives with Samvel’s retired parents. Back in 1995, Samvel owned an old BMW which he broke into parts and sold. The demand for used parts was growing then, and Samvel started buying broken cars and selling them in parts, operating from his workshop. The clients like Samvel’s service, although the demand has now shifted to brand new car parts which he currently doesn’t have. Being the main breadwinner in the family, it is vital for Samvel to bring some fresh zest into his business and expand it. With the help of the loan, Samvel will be able to travel to the neighbor country to purchase the new parts and to meet the clients' demands.

loans.use: For travelling to the neighbour country to purchase brand new car parts.

loans.name: Paix Plus Group

texts.en:
Evelyne M. is the leader of this community bank named “Paix Plus”, which is composed of twenty micro-entrepreneurs united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses.

Evelyne is 30 years old and is the mother of five children, three of whom go to school. She sells loaves of bread and has been in business since 2007. She started with capital of $50 and, currently, her business brings in a benefit of $60 per week.

After learning through her friend about HOPE’s loan program, Evelyne decided to join one of its groups in November 2008. She has already received five loans from HOPE that she repaid correctly. With her next loan she is planning to purchase more bags of loaves of bread to increase the inventory of her business.

Evelyne’s dream is to be a provider of these products in her area. She runs her business in the south-western area of Kinshasa.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of loaves of bread to increase her inventory

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Dominador

texts.en: Dominador A.'s main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. He is 58 years old and has been married to his wife, Veronica, for 30 years now. They are from the town of Sta. Josefa. Dominador has been in his business for over 22 years. Dominador joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Dominador has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Dominador is requesting a new loan of 13,000 Philippine pesos which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be his fifth loan from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve his business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. In addition to credit for its clients, CEVI also provides savings, insurance and training through regular cluster group meetings. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Gédéon Plus Group

texts.en:
Marie-Claire S. is the leader of this community bank named “Gédéon Plus”, which is composed of nineteen micro-entrepreneurs who are united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through HOPE RDC with the goal of developing their businesses.

Marie-Claire, 42, is married and is the mother of six children aged between 2 and 4 years of whom four attend school.

Marie-Claire sells shoes and has been in business for many years. She has acquired solid experience and her business has prospered thanks to good management and accumulated profits. Currently, she earns a profit of $30 every week.

Marie-Claire intends, with this next loan, to purchase thirty pairs of shoes and miscellaneous goods to increase the inventory of her business. Her dream is to open a general boutique in her area.

loans.use: To purchase thirty pairs of shoes and miscellaneous goods

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Pashakul

texts.ru: Ачелдиев Пашакул проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 59 лет. Вдовец, имеет 4 детей. Образование средне - специальное, электрик. По специальности проработал 20 лет. Сейчас он занимается растениеводством. Арендует небольшой земельный участок, где выращивает овощи. Имеет богатый опыт в этой области. Уже 30 лет как он занимается растениеводством. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений, чтобы получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Pashakul A. lives in the Shahrituz area. He is 59 years old, a widower, and has four children. Pashakul has a special high school education as an electrician. He worked in his trade for twenty years. Now, he is farming. He rents the plot where he grows vegetables and fruit. He has vast experience in this. He has been farming for thirty years. He is taking out a loan to buy mineral fertilizer in order to reap a good harvest.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Koffi

texts.fr: ce monsieur exerce comme activité généartrice de revenu le commerce de téléphones portables, des cartes de recharges et des accessoires, il exerce ce commerce à akodessewa qui est un quartier dynamique. il a commencé ce commerce en 2003. il veut gonfler son stock pour accroître ses recettes, il sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour compléter ses économies et acheter  des téléphones portables, des cartes de recharge, de même que les accessoires. il est marié et père d'un enfant c'est avec le revenu de son commerce qu'il subvient aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
This gentleman makes his living selling mobile phones, prepaid cards and accessories. His business is based in Akodessewa, a bustling neighborhood; he started it in 2003. To increase turnover, he wants to build his inventory, and so is asking WAGES for a loan to buy phones, cards and accessories. He is married and has one child. With his income he is able to pay for his family's needs.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy mobile phones, prepaid cards and accessories

loans.name: Abror

texts.ru: Хайдаров Аброр проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 44 года.  Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Аброр имеет средне - специальное образование, механизатор. Работает по профессии. Кроме того более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. Арендует земельный участок, где выращивает овощи и фрукты. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Abror H. lives in the Shahrituz area. He is 44 years old, married, and has five children. His wife is a housewife. Abror has a vocational education as a machine operator. He works in his trade. Additionally, he has been farming for more than ten years. He rents the plot where he grows vegetables and fruit. He is taking out a loan to buy mineral fertilizer.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Abdurasul

texts.en: A. Abdurasul is a very hardworking and responsible entrepreneur. He and his family live in Shahrituz, Tajikistan. He is married and has five children. Abdurasul works in the central city market selling men’s national skullcaps and chapans (caftans). His business is characterized by stability and consistent growth. He has been working in the market for 17 years. Abdurasul likes to work for himself. His business has been the main source of income for his whole family. Today Abdurasul would like to ask for a loan of $2800 US to purchase new inventory. We believe Abdurasul‘s drive for success will help this young entrepreneur succeed and thrive in business. You can be an important part of the growth of Abdurasul’s business. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to sell

loans.name: Teko Robert

texts.fr: gadzi teko est un homme  très dynamique, il est marié et père de 2 enfants , il y a 5 ans de cela il s'est lancé dans le commerce de détail de vidéo cassettes, CD audio, baffle et autres. il a ouvert une petite cabine dans laquelle il fait son commerce. la demande actuelle de ses clients est élevée, pour les satisfaire il doit se réapprovisionner raison pour laquelle il demande son premier prêt de WAGES pour l'achat de 6 baffles, 4 amplificateurs et des CD
texts.en:
Gadzi Teko is a very energetic man, married with two children. Five years ago he began selling videocassettes, audio CDs, speaker baffles and other products. He opened a small store for his business. Customer demand has increased, and to satisfy it he needs to build inventory. For that reason, he is asking for his first loan from WAGES to buy 6 baffles, 4 speakers and CDs.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baffles, speakers and audio CDs

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en: B. Dilbar is 47 years old. Together with her husband, Adolat, she has raised three children. Dilbar has been running a drugstore for 5 years. She sells only certified medicines. The drugstore is located in the center of town which allows her to have many clients and customers. Now Dilbar is requesting $3000 US. With expansion of the business and consequent increase in income, Dilbar is planning to provide all her children with higher education. Being a very accurate person by nature, Dilbar is sure, and would like to ensure the lenders, that she will repay the loan without any delay. This money will help her accomplish her goals in a short time. Your generosity can change their lives. More about Tajikistan and IMON International: Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its epic mountain passes and its rich history which includes its place as a key post along the Silk Road and events at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has produced famous thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. A civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged an already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural productivity and the manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent viable business prospects. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase medicaments for expanding the business

loans.name: Rodel

texts.en:
This is Rodel D., 40, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Rosanna D., a variety store owner, and is the father of two children, both of whom are already in college. By the grace of God, Rodel has managed to support his children's schooling up to the college level. This is a dream come true for most Filipino parents like Rodel, as he himself has been to college and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Rodel operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store selling groceries, toiletries and beverages in the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos (PHP) worth of cooking oil or an egg. Rodel earns money by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling them retail. 

Rodel’s edge over other competitors is that he also owns a videoke machine (a karaoke with a television displaying entertaining scenery and song lyrics) alongside his store. Filipinos never miss an opportunity to sing, and a videoke session is what many Filipinos do to pass time and have fun. Rodel’s store is located next to his house. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help him continue the operation of his business, Rodel is requesting a 18,000 PHP loan. He will be using the loan to buy more products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Rodel dreams of being able to give his children a high quality education through all his hard work in the business. He also hopes to have his house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: To buy more groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
M. Saodat is an enterprising, capable and very hard-working woman. She lives in Shahrituz, Tajikistan, and sells kids' clothes and toys. She began her own business because her husband’s salary was not sufficient for their large family, including their four children. Her business is allowing Saodat to provide her children with the necessary food and education. 

Currently, she needs a loan of $2,000 to buy merchandise in order to increase sales. Saodat wants to continue to support her children and only wishes to work in order to achieve this. Support her!  
 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new clothes and toys for kids

loans.name: Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.fr: N. Emmanuel est homme né en 1976 dans le secteur de Muhima, district de Nyarugenge, province de Kigali, capital du Rwanda.il est marié, et il a deux enfants Il fait le commerce de pièces de rechanges en secteur de Gatsata, il est membre du groupe solidaire appelé ABISHYIZEHAMWE, il est donc un de trois membres de ce groupe il se trouve au milieu sur la photo c'est-à-dire le deuxième à gauche ou à droite , son niveau d'étude est primaire. Avec le prêt il veut acheter des bandes freins, clignota ires, jantes pour les détailler, la clientèle des ces articles lui permet de vider très rapidement le stock et avoir la nécessité d’acheter et vendre beaucoup d’articles. Les épargnes continuelles lui permet de payer le minerval pour sa femme qui étudie  en cinquième année secondaire et fait sciences humaines, dans l’avenir il veut avoir sa propre maison car il loue, et planifier pour le bon futur de  sa famille.
texts.en:
Emmanuel N. was born in 1976 in the Muhima neighborhood of the district of Nyarugenge in the province of Kigali, Rwanda's capital. He is married with two children. He sells auto parts in the Gatsata neighborhood, and is a member of the Abishyizehamwe cooperative group. The group has three members; he is in the middle in the photo. He finished primary school. With his loan he plans to buy brake linings, turn signals, and wheel rims. Customers for these items rapidly deplete his stock and he needs to buy and sell many items. His savings will allow him to pay his wife's enrollment fee (she is studying social sciences in her fifth year of secondary school). He hopes to buy his own house -- he rents now -- and to assure his family's future.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wheel rims and brake linings for retail sale

loans.name: Bozorgul

texts.en: Bozorgul is a very shy woman, but also very hardworking as a farmer and as the mother of four young children. She and her husband cultivate potatoes and corn. At the same time, they are engaged in raising cattle. What they urgently need right now are fertilizers and other chemicals for the care of their crops so that they can produce a product that is in line with the demands of the market. Bozorgul needs your help to buy the fertilizers, which are the most expensive and most necessary inputs for the cultivation of her crops. Her goal is to achieve better profits and benefits in the market. Bozorgul doesn’t just need good land; she also needs a friendly hand to help her out. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer for growing seasonal vegetables

loans.name: Joey

texts.en:
This is Joey M., 39-year-old resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Irene M., a housewife.

Joey operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five Philippine pesos' (Php) worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Joey earns profit by getting supplies at a wholesale price and selling them at a piece rate. 

Joey also oversees operation of a public utility jeepney, which does rounds on the highways near his home. Joey's store is located adjacent to his house. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help him continue operation of his business, he is requesting a Php10,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.
  
Joey dreams that his children will finish their education.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: G. kokou est un déclarant en douane, actuellement il a de la peine pour exerce son activité à cause du déplacement qui lui coûte cher. pour trouver une solution à cela il sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour l'achat d'un moyen de transport qui est la moto. il est marié, père d'un enfant, il vit avec sa famille dans le quartier d'attiégou à Lomé.
texts.en:
Kokou G. is a customs official. He is having a difficult time operating his business at present because transportation costs him a great deal. In order to resolve this problem, he is requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase a motorcycle as a means of transportation. He is married, the father of a child and lives with his family in Lomé’s Attiégou district.

Translated from French by Connie Archea, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
This is Merlita D. P., a 43-year-old resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Orlando D. P., a seaman. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is still in elementary school, while one is currently enrolled in college. By the grace of God, Merlita has managed to support her children’s schooling. At this time, she is working hard to send one of them to college -- a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Merlita, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Merlita manages a retail store attached to her house and sells groceries, condiments and beverages to her neighbors as customers. She also maintains a direct-selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through popular direct-selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and others. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php20,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Merlita dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also hopes that this year, her husband will be able to work again outside the country as a seaman.

loans.use: Buy orders for her customers and additional items to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, oil, biscuits, sugar and peanuts

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
This is Gloria S., a widow at 70 and a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She maintains a simple life, having no other opportunities in life except for business as she only possesses an elementary diploma. She struggles hard with her business and makes sure that it is successful and stable.

Gloria operates a fruit stand. She buys seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like pineapples, which are grown mostly in the southern region of Luzon. She also sells green and ripe mangoes, melons, watermelons and other Filipino fruit staples. Also in her product inventory are different species of bananas. Apples, pears and lychees are fruits that are offered a few times a year. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 200 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fruit to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Gloria dreams to save up enough for her future retirement.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of fruit to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Atigo

texts.fr: atigo sodekémé exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de bois de chauffage, elle fait ce commerce depuis 10 ans déjà, elle a une clientèle élevée et beaucoup de femme qui vendent les boissons locales viennent acheter du bois de chauffage pour préparer le tchoucoutchou. le crédit qu'elle demande lui permettra de compléter ses économies et d'acheter du bois pour le chauffage. elle est veuve et a 4 enfants, son activité lui permet de subvenir aux charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
For the past ten yeras, Atigo Sodekémé has made her living selling firewood. Her customer base is primarily made up of women who produce local beverages and need the firewood to make tchoucoutchou. The loan that she is seeking would enable her to purchase more firewood; as she is a widow with four children, her business enables her to meet her family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en:
This is Franklin B., a 42-year-old resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Mary Jane B., an employee.

Franklin operates a mobile merchandise store. He sells accessories and basic commodities like detergent soaps, repacked sugar, salt, cooking oil, soy sauce, junk foods, biscuits and generic medicines. He delivers these goods, using his own motorcycle, to the retail stores that are also his patrons every day. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help him continue operating his business, he is requesting a Php12,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products to be incorporated into his current inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.
  
Franklin dreams to have his own department store and become one of the wealthiest and most successful men in the Philippines.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of products to be incorporated into his current inventory

loans.name: Ruth United Group

texts.en:
Joseph B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Ruth United. He is 21 years old, single and was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of financial support.  

For two years, he has been selling used clothes in Harbel Market Firestone, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 4,000-Liberian-Dollars portion of this 20,000-Liberian-Dollars group loan to buy more used clothes. He describes himself as kind and determined.

His goal is to improve his business and go back to school.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Aram

texts.en:
Aram M. is running a small café business in a market area. Aram’s wife is an experienced cook, preparing delicious meals for the clients. The couple’s daughter also works in the café, serving the clients. The café has a delivery service, which is quite in demand. 

However, their current ovens are old and not for restaurant business, causing a delay in the food production. To keep up with the demand, Aram requires a new fridge to hygienically store the raw products, a modern high-productivity oven and a fryer to produce pizza, lahmajo (flatbread baked with meat), hot dogs and other meals and snacks. This will increase the family business drastically and keep the clientele happy.

loans.use: New fridge, high-productivity oven and fryer

loans.name: Rasul

texts.en:
Rasul D. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more rice and beans to cook and sell. Rasul is 33 years old and married to a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more rice and beans to cook and sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is married with four children, all of whom are  at school. She also takes care of her in-laws. She owns a stall in Kalerwe market, selling bananas. 

She plans to use this loan to a buy more bunches of bananas. She buys these bananas from villages of Masaka in south central Uganda. Mary uses public transport to and from Masaka, where she goes for shopping once a week. She has been in this business for 10 years and she also sells furniture to get additional income. 

She receives an average of 30 people and sells both on a retail and wholesale basis. Her customers are the people in the market and nearby communities. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are transportation and seasonality.   

She aspires to see her business grow big and to build her own house. Mary decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital. 

She resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and market dues.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock to increase his product range

loans.name: Kukartuna Group

texts.en:
Ruth B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Kukartuna. She is 45 years old, married and has one child who is 11 years old. 
She was only able to attend school to 3rd grade due to lack of financial support. She cares for one sibling.

For 4 years she has been selling rubber bowls and cups in Cotton Tree Community in Harbel, Margibi County, Liberia.

She plans to use her 9,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 45,000 Liberian Dollars group loan to buy more rubber bowls and cups. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Her goal is to improve her business.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Joseph is inset at the lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more rubber bowls and cups

loans.name: Carolyn

texts.en:
This is Carolyn B., 33, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Almario B., a businessman. She is the mother of two children, both of whom are still in elementary school. Carolyn hopes that, with the grace of God, she will be able to support her children's education until they reach their college years. It is a dream for most Filipino parents like Carolyn as she herself is a college undergraduate and believes that this is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Carolyn operates a junk shop. Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines and, while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic and paper. They sell these to junk shops like Carolyn’s for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her to continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy trash from collectors. She expects a boost in her business income as the business expands. 
 
Carolyn dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through her hard work in her business. She also hopes to expand her business so that it will be a stable and income generating legacy for her children and her family.

loans.use: to add to her cash reserves used to buy trash from collectors

loans.name: Rejoice

texts.en:
Rejoice M. is currently in the business of selling bedsheets, clothes and gowns at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock accessories such as necklaces and ear-rings.  Rejoice is 46 years old and is married to a business man. She has 4 children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a pharmacy.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock accessories to sell

loans.name: Ma. Ligaya

texts.en:
This is Ma. Ligaya B., 40, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rosendo B., a contractor. She is the mother of four children, two of whom are in high school while the other two are still in elementary schools. By the grace of God, Ligaya has managed to support her children's schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send them all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Ligaya as she herself is college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave to their children.

Ma. Ligaya operates a junk shop and a retail store. She is also a fruit dealer, buying fruit wholesale and retailing it in the market. Trash is not actively segregated in the Philippines and, while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic and paper. They sell these to junk shops like Juanita’s for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200, 300, and 350 in sales every day in the junk shop, retail store and fruit vending business respectively.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a Php48,000 loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy trash from collectors. She also will also invest a portion of the loan to buy groceries for her store and wholesale fruits to be incorporated into her current product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Ligaya dreams of being able to give her all her children a good, high quality education through her hard work in her business.

loans.use: to add to her cash reserves used buy trash from collectors; to buy groceries and wholesale fruits for resale

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is married to a welder. They have five children who all go to school.  She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. 

She owns a store where she sells charcoal.  Annet wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She has been in this business for sixteen years. 


As well as this charcoal business, she sells cooked food. She sells her charcoal in Naguru market and sells to all categories of people. Annet works seven days a week.  


Her business challenge is the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She doesn’t incur any transport costs because she  buys from her home from suppliers who source stock from villages. She aspires to seeing her business expand and to selling wholesale only.  


Annet resides in and  owns a two roomed house. Her family has access  to electricity and piped water. Her  monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty R. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste from home. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of charcoal to sell.  Betty is 32 years old and is married to a security guard. She has 3 children who go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights, and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to stock bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
This is Erlinda B., 47, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She has one child with whom she lives. 

Erlinda operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil or an egg. Juanita earns a living by getting supplies at wholesale price and selling at piece rate. Erlinda’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her maintain business operations, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Erlinda hopes to be a successful and well-off businesswoman someday

loans.use: to buy stock to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Alaisha

texts.en:
Alaisha is married with three children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (brothers and sisters).  She owns a stall where she sells fruits and vegetables like onions, tomatoes, and Irish potatoes.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of Irish potatoes and boxes of tomatoes, onions and pineapples. She has been in this business for four years.  

Besides this food business, she also owns four rooms for renting.  She works seven days a week.  Her business challenges include the transportation of sacks of onions and Irish potatoes from Nakawa to Kisaasi market where she has her stall. She wants to see her business grow and start selling on a wholesale basis only.  

Alaisha joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital for her business.  She rents and resides in a two-room house where the family has access to electricity but no piped water.  Her monthly expenses include school fees, food and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of Irish potatoes, boxes of tomatoes. onions and pineapples

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
This is Ma. Elena F., a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Roger F., who works as security personnel, and is the mother of a high-school-aged child. By the grace of God, Elena has managed to support her child’s schooling. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her child all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Elena, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Ma. Elena operates a variety store. She also rents out a few rooms for transients and students. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for buying one sachet of shampoo, one egg or 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil. Juanita earns by getting supplies at a wholesale price and selling in piece rate. Elena’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.50 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 25,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
 
Elena dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: to buy quantities of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Mercelita

texts.en:
This is Mercelita D., 28, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Albert Daniego, a factory worker, and the mother of four children, all of whom are still in elementary school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college, which is a dream for most Filipino parents like Mercelita. She herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Mercelita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for buying one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.30 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Mercelita dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: to buy more quantities of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
This is Rosario B., a widow at age 43, resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She has four children and three grandchildren, courtesy of her oldest child. Her three younger children are still in elementary school.

Rosario operates a buy-and-sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sell piecemeal with a little profit. Products can range from furniture to household appliances, electronic devices, clothing and other products. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.65 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Rosario dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: buy more quantities and varieties of products to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with five children and all her children go to school.  She also takes care of her brother’s son. 

She is a mushroom grower in Kisaasi and sells mushrooms to all the supermarkets in Kisaasi and some in Kampala city. She wants this loan to buy more millet and seeds for mushroom growing. She has been in this mushroom growing business for three years. Betty sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. 

Besides this business she also owns rental rooms. She works six days a week. Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters.  She wants to start exporting her mushrooms to other African countries. 

Betty joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital and because of their low interest rates compared to other MFI’s.  She owns and lives in a three-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, medication and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more millet and mushroom seeds

loans.name: Anicia

texts.en:
This is Anicia L., 41, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Emmanuel, an employee, and the mother of four children, three of whom are already working.

Anicia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for buying one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Anicia earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Anicia’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.30 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Anicia dreams that her children will have stable and successful futures.

loans.use: to buy more quantities of products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
This is Ma. Luisa T., 54, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Dante T. and the mother of three children.

Luisa operates a variety store and bakery. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for buying one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Ma. Luisa earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Ma. Luisa’s store and bakery is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of $4.40 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 34,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She also will invest some of the loan to purchase bread-making ingredients like flour, sugar and butter. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ma. Luisa dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: to buy more quantities of products to expand her inventory, and to purchase bread-making ingredients like flour, sugar and butter

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
This is Virginia T., 42, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Joseph T., an OFW (overseas Filipino worker), and the mother of three children, one of whom is in college, while the other two are in high school and elementary school. By the grace of God, Virginia has managed to support her older child's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send the other two to college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Virginia, as she herself has been a college undergraduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Virginia maintains a direct-selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct-selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct-selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and the difference makes up the profits that dealers are counting on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She averages a minimum of 200 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 8,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
  
Virginia dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: to buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Las Naranjas Group

texts.es:
L. señora Rosalinda Hernández Pérez  vive en L. ribera Santa Catarina municipio D. Copainalá estado D. Chiapas, México. Tiene 27 años D. edad es madre soltera con un pequeño D. tres años. Tiene L. actividad D. venta D. ropa, L. cual realiza en las comunidades cercanas a su colonia, lleva practicando esta actividad hace dos años y es D. ésta actividad D. donD. obtiene ingresos para sostenerse con su hijo. 
Lo que L. motivo a practicar esta actividad fue su hijo quien necesita mucho D. elL., para  poder criarlo y darle una buena educación  ya que no cuenta en el apoyo D. su pareja. ElL. comenta que seguirá luchando por su bienestar y el D. su familia y así salir adelante y deseaq que su negocio crezca día a día.
Rosalinda solicitó un crédito a FRAC para ello formó un grupo llamado “Las naranjas”,  L. cual se integra D. cuatro personas, cada una con diferente actividad, L. razón del nombre es porque en ese lugar se da L. cosecha D. esta fruta.
ElL. le gustaría tener un local donD. vender su mercancía, tener ahorros para apoyarse  en lo necesario y darle a su hijo un mejor futuro D. vida.
Las persona que integran el grupo son: doña Teresa Juárez Vázquez elL. se dedica a L. venta D. ropa,  María Vitalina venD. ropa y café molido y Silvina Aguilar R. venD. hoja D. guineo.
texts.en:
Señora Rosalinda Hernández Pérez lives in the riversiD. settlement of Santa Catarina, near Copainalá in the state of Chiapas, Mexico. She is 27 years old, and a single mother with a little boy, aged 3. She sells clothes in the nearby communities. She has been doing this work for the past 2 years, and from it she earns enough to take care of herself and her son. It was to meet the needs of her young son that Rosalinda took up this work, to be able to bring him up and give him a good education without the support of a partner. She is striving to ensure his wellbeing and that of her family, and that is why she goes out and works at growing her business day by day. Rosalinda would like to have a place where she can sell her merchandise. She also wants to save up money so she has it when she needs it, and she wants to give her son a better future in life. Seeking a loan from [field partner] FRAC, Rosalinda has formed a group called "Las Naranjas" ("The Oranges"). Ther are four people in the group, who each work for themselves. They chose this name because the place they come from is known for its harvest of oranges. The people in the group are: doña Teresa Juárez Vázquez, who sells also clothes; María Vitalina, who sells clothes and ground coffee; and Silvina Aguilar R., who sells guineo leaves (similar to banana leaves, these are used in making local dishes such as tamales).

Translated from Spanish by Rosa Oswald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes such as trousers, blouses and shirts

loans.name: Nuevo Dia Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Nueva Vida inicia su ciclo 9 con 13 socias que realizan diferentes negocios.
Como es el caso D. L. señora Candy que es L. presidenta del Banco Comunal por primera vez, Candy es soltera y vive con padres, llego a Finca Perú por invitación D. una amiga y lo que mas le agrada son las capacitaciones y L. educación en valores.
Candy tiene una peluquería en un local alquilado ubicado en el centro D. L. ciudad llamada Jair Stilos, negocio que inicio hace 3 años y ahora esta mas granD., cuenta con L. ayuda D. 5 personas. Candy solicita un préstamo D. 450 soles para L. compra D. tintes, peines. 
Su mayor sueño es especializarse en temas D. cosmeatría y además D. iniciar otros proyectos.
texts.en:
The Nueva Vida (New Life) Communal Bank is starting its ninth cyle with 13 members who have different businesses. One of the members is Candy, who is the president of the communal bank for the first time. Candy is single and lives with her parents. She came to Finca Perú by invitation of a friend. What she likes the most are the trainings and the values education. Candy has a beauty salon in a rented place, which is located in the center of the city called Jair Stilos. She started her business three years ago. Now it is bigger, and she has five people helping her. Candy is requesting a loan for 450 soles to buy tints and combs. Her biggest dream is to specialize in cosmetology and to start other projects.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tints and combs

loans.name: Jose Enrique

texts.es:
Jose Enrique R. S. tiene 23 años.  Es casado y vive con su esposa e hijo, Tonio (4), en el cantón de Guaranda en la provincia de Bolívar. 

Jose es un socio de la ventanilla rural Patrón San Juan, que está ubicada a media hora de Guaranda. Son 16 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a cultivos de papas y maíz. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Jose trabaja en la albañilería y la agricultura, cultivando papas, trigo, cebada y habas. Tiene también animales, como cuyes y cerdos, que utilizan por el consumo propio. Realiza sus compras y sus ventas en Guaranda.

Solicita el préstamo para el cultivo de papas: comprar insumos, fertilizantes y semillas. Quisiera tener más terreno para cultivar otros productos. Dice que faltan medios de transportes para poder vender los productos (no hay bus por aquí y la gente no tiene carros). 

Le gusta jugar fútbol y fiestas de noviembre donde realizan comidas típicas y bailes
texts.en:
Jose Enrique R. S. is 23 years old. He is married and lives with his wife and child, Tonio (4), Guaranda canton in the province of Bolivar. Jose is a member of the rural bank Patrón San Juan, which is located a half an hour from Guaranda. It has 16 members in total, most of whom grow potatoes and corn. This is the first loan that they have taken out with the Cooperativa San José. Jose works in masonry and agriculture, growing potatoes, wheat, barley and beans. He also has animals such as guinea pigs and pigs, which he uses for his own consumption. He buys and sells in Guaranda. He is asking for the loan for growing potatoes: to buy materials, fertilizers and seeds. He would like to have more land to grow other products. He says that he lacks transportation to be able to sell the products (there is no bus nearby and people don't have cars). He likes to play soccer and he likes the festivals in November when they have traditional food and dances.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For growing potatoes: to buy materials, fertilzer and seeds.

loans.name: Nuru-Lumo Group

texts.en:
Charity M., age 48, is married with three children, ages 22, 18 and 14. She has operated a general store business for ten years now.  She works from 6:30am to 10pm daily and is able to make a monthly profit of about $168.

This will be Charity’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loan to increase her business sales and has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to start a poultry business. 

Charity will share this loan with her loan group, Nuru-Lumo, which totals fifteen members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture Charity is sitting behind the table, the first one on the right.

loans.use: To start a poultry business

loans.name: San Jose Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal San Jose inicia con 17 socias.
Graciela es presidenta del Banco Comunal por segunda vez y es socia hace 8 meses y lo que le agrada es el incentivo al ahorro. 
Graciela es soltera y tiene 4 hijos por quienes trabaja para brindarles todo lo mejor, su sueño es que sus hijos sean profesionales y construir su casa D. material noble porque ahora su casa es D. material rustico, vive en la Asentamiento Humano San José cerca del penal D. la ciudad, Graciela venD. comida rápida como salchipapas, hamburguesas D. manera ambulatoria en una avenida transitada D. la ciudad para lo cual cuenta con una carreta, actividad que realiza todos los días por las noches desD. las 5 D. la tarD. hasta las 5 D. la mañana, además viaja a las fiestas patronales en donD. permanece por algunos días vendiendo sus productos.
Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. papa, aceite, descartables.
texts.en:
The San José Communal Bank began with 17 members. Graciela is the president of the communal bank for the second time, and what she likes about it is the incentive to save money.

Graciela is single and has 4 children for whom she works to offer a better life. Her dreams are that her children will become professionals and that she will be able to build her house with stronger materials because now her house is built with primitive material. She lives in Asentamiento Humano San José near the city jail. Graciela sells fast food such as salchipapas (fried potatoes and sausage) and hamburgers in an itinerant fashion from a pushcart on a congested avenue in the city. She carries out this business every day from 5 in the afternoon until 5 in the morning. In addition, she travels to festivals where she stays for a few days selling her products. Her loan will be invested in potatoes, cooking oil, and disposable plates.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of potatoes, cooking oil, and disposable plates

loans.name: Janneth Eulalia

texts.es:
Janeth es una socia de la ventanilla rural Patrón San Juan, que está ubicada a media hora de Guaranda. Son 16 socios en total, que en la mayoridad se dedican a cultivos de papas y maíz. Esto es el primer préstamo que ellos sacan con la Cooperativa San José.

Janneth trabaja en la agricultura, cultivando papas, trigo, cebada y mora. Al mismo tiempo estudia enfermería en la Universidad. Realiza sus compras y sus ventas en Guaranda.

Solicita el préstamo para la compra de insumos para la siembra. Su sueño es ser una enfermera y poder seguir estudiando para poder ser un buen profesional. 

Le gusta leer libros y escuchar música.
texts.en:
Janeth is a member of the Patrón San Juan Communal Bank, which is located a half hour from Guaranda. There are 16 members in all. Most of them devote themselves to growing potatoes and corn. This is their first loan with the Cooperativa San José. Janeth works in agriculture; she grows potatoes, wheat, barley, and blackberries. At the same time she is studying nursing at the university. She makes her purchases and sales in Guaranda. She is requesting the loan to buy supplies for planting. Her dream is to be a nurse and to continue studying in order to be able to be a good professional. She likes to read books and listen to music.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for planting

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya is married. She is an entrepreneur from Melitopol, where she runs a small clothing sales business. Natalya sells women’s outer clothing items at a local market. She is an experienced market vendor, and has been running this business for twelve years. Currently, Natalya has 100,000 UAH worth of inventory. Her monthly revenue is about $1,150. 

Natalya has used micro-loans before and found them very helpful for her business development. This time Natalya is requesting a loan of 20,000 UAH to increase the selection of clothing merchandise she offers for sale in her kiosk. 

Natalya is known as an open and lively woman who cares about her customers' needs. As she provides for the needs of others, she will be able to generate the necessary funds to adequately provide for herself and her family.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of her inventory

loans.name: Arenal Group

texts.es:
Arenal es un grupo conformado por once personas (en la foto Rosa N. de blusa azul cielo y el señor Tomas solo son ahorradores, es decir, no pidieron crédito) que luchan por un futuro mejor a pesar de las adversidades que se le presentan día a día. Ellos se ubican en la Comunidad de La paz, Estado de México. Estan muy contentos ya que hasta ahora los créditos solicitados les han sido de mucha ayuda y esperan seguir trabajando con Fundación Realidad.

Juanita González originaria del Estado de VeraC., tiene 48 años de edad, su familia la integran, su esposo quien trabaja de músico y su hijo de 10 años (estudia la primaria). Aunque han pasado etapas difíciles siempre están luchando por salir adelante y tener una mejor calidad de vida. Adrián su hijo tiene una discapacidad (labio leporino) así que siempre se ha visto en la necesidad de buscar medios de ingresos para los estudios y tratamientos que el requiere y así brindarle un mejor futuro. Ella comenzó con la venta de tortillas, tiempo después las ventas habían bajado y ya no era muy rentable seguir vendiendo así que decidió comenzar con una actividad que beneficiara tanto a su familia como a su comunidad así que comenzó con la venta de abarrotes (frijol, arroz, azúcar, etc.). Abre su tiendita toda la semana desde las siete de la mañana tratando de tener siempre surtido. Los planes de Juanita son poder ampliar un poco más su tiendita. El crédito solicitado lo tiene designado para la compra de mercancía básica, así que ella agradece la ayuda que le brinda Kiva a través de Fundación Realidad ya que de esa forma puede ayudar a su comunidad y a su familia.

Los demás integrantes del grupo podrán hacer realidad muchos de sus planes y beneficiar así sus comunidades.

María Guadalupe Z. O. (Venta de colchas y edredones)
María Luisa N. González (Billar)
María del Carmen A. D. (Venta de zapatos por catalogo)
María Vianey González C. (Transporte Publico (combi))
Yemina R. González (Venta de Jugos)
Amalia H. C. (Venta de Frutas y Legumbres)
María del Socorro A. D. (Venta de Artículos Domésticos)
Verónica S. C. (Venta de Antojitos (Tamales))
Alicia B. M. (Manualidades)
Daria H. C. (Venta de Cosméticos por catalogo)
texts.en:
Arenal is a group comprised of 11 people (in the photo Rosa N., the lady that has a sky blue blouse on, and Tomas are solely savers, that is to say that they are not asking for a loan). The members fight for a better future in spite of the daily adversities that they encounter. They are located in the La Paz community in the state of Mexico. They are very happy because up until now the requested loans have been very helpful. They hope to continue working with the Fundación Realidad. Juanita González is from the state of VeraC.. She is 48 years old, and her family consists of her husband, who works as a musician, and their ten year old son (he is in elementary school). Even though they have passed through some difficult stages, they are always fighting to get ahead and have a better quality of life. Adrián, their son, has a disability (harelip). That is why they have always seen the necessity of looking for means of income for his studies and the treatment he requires. That will provide him with a better future. She started selling tortillas. Some time later the sales went down, and it was not profitable to continue selling them. That is how she decided to start an activity that would benefit her family as much as her community. She started selling groceries (beans, rice, and sugar, etc.). She opens her little store all week at seven in the morning, and she is trying to always keep it stocked. Juana’s plans are to be able to expand her little store a bit more. The requested loan is to buy basic merchandise. She is grateful for the help that Kiva offers through the Fundación Realidad. This way she is able to help her community and her family. The rest of the group members will be able to make a lot of their plans a reality and therefore benefit their communities. María Guadalupe Z. O. (Sells bedspreads and quilts) María Luisa N. González (Billiards) María del Carmen A. D. (Sells shoes by catalog) María Vianey González C. (Public Transportation - Minivan) Yemina R. González (Sells juice) Amalia H. C. (Sells fruit and vegetables) María del Socorro A. D. (Sells domestic items) Verónica S. C. ( Sells snacks - Tamales) Alicia B. M. (Handicrafts)

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries, shoes, quilts, oranges straws, fruit and vegetables, cosmetics, ribbon, and artificial flowers

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is married. She owns a small business selling children’s clothing in a local mall in Vinogradovo, Western Ukraine. The favorable location of Angela’s shop adds to her good sales rates. Angela has been in the business for 8 years. Presently, she has about 65,000 UAH in merchandise. Her income amounts to 6,000 UAH. 

Some of the major characteristics of Angela’s business are stability and consistency. This is partly due to the financial assistance she received in previous years. Angela is very optimistic and cheerful which has helped her fulfill her business goals in the past. She was able to start a second sales location last year. She hopes to develop her business further. Angela is requesting a loan of 12,000 UAH to purchase more inventory and increase her sales.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory

loans.name: Marisol

texts.es: Marisol tiene 30 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en una casa alquilada. Hace más de 10 años se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente cultiva papa, maíz y algunas hortalizas sobre terrenos le fue heredado por sus padres, una vez cosechados sus productos, son comercializados en el mercado mayorista de Tarma, lugar donde obtiene las mejores ganancias. Lo que mas le gusta de su trabajo  es cuidar  sus cultivos de las plagas, ya que estos afectan en el desarrollo de su cosecha, sin embargo considera que lo mas difícil son las jornadas arduas de siembra y de cosecha para lo cual requiere de mas esfuerzo y mano de obra. Con el tiempo espera que sus cultivos mejoren para que pueda vender toda su cosechas a un mejor precio y de esa manera establecer su economía. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP, esta muy contenta de  saber que tiene un apoyo financiero ya que siempre ha demostrado  ser responsable en sus pagos, además  le agrada ser parte de su grupo comunal porque  todos sus integrantes son personas responsables y muy solidarias, agradece además a las personas que serán gestoras del préstamo que solicita, puesto que le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de sacos de abono para su próxima campaña de siembra.
texts.en:
Marisol is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a rented house. She’s been farming for more than ten years, specifically raising potatoes, corn, and a few types of vegetables, on land that she inherited from her parents. Once her products are harvested, she sells them in the main marketplace in Tarma, where she can fetch the best prices. What she enjoys most about her work is caring for her crops so that they do not fall victims to diseases that affects their development and harvest. What she finds most challenging are the trips to the field to plant and then to harvest, which requires more effort and more labor. Eventually she expects her crops to improve so that she can sell her entire harvest for a better price and be able to establish herself economically. This will be her second loan through MFP and she is very happy to have financial backing, especially since she has demonstrated herself to be responsible with her payments. She also likes being a part of her communal group, because all of its members are responsible and united. She is especially thankful to those who have helped her get this loan, which will be very helpful to her business’ progress. She will use the money from this loan to buy sacs of fertilizer for her next planting.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fertilizer

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa, de  35 años, vive en la casa de sus padres, en compañía de ellos y  sus hermanas menores.Se dedica a brindar el servicio de  movilidad, para la  empresa de transportes de su padre. Inicialmente no percibía sueldo alguno, y hoy en día recibe un sueldo como el resto de empleados. Su trabajo consiste en  distribuir  los materiales de fabricación (clavos, soquetes y demás accesorios  de ferretería) a los minoristas, que la contratan para que preste el servicio, ya que se ha ganado la  confianza de todos ellos. Sus clientes  se hallan dispersos en los barrios marginales de la ciudad; por lo que organiza la distribución de acuerdo a las rutas. Durante estos  dos años que tiene laborando, no ha tenido  mayores riesgos; por lo que se siente muy satisfecha, además el trabajo es tranquilo y las ganancias regulares. Para el futuro tiene planeado comprarse un auto propio, para mejorar sus ingresos.Es el  treceavo préstamo que tiene con MFP, y sabe que el dinero  le será muy beneficioso, por lo que se compromete en pagar sus cuotas puntualmente.Rosa tiene planeado invertir el dinero solicitado en la conversión del tanque de gasolina, del auto con el que trabaja,  por el de gas, para ahorrar en combustible, y de esta manera espera continuar progresando.
texts.en:
Rosa is 35 years old and lives in her parent’s house with her younger sisters. She provides mobility services for her father’s transportation company. Initially she was not receiving any salary, but now receives a salary as the other employees. Her job is to distribute manufacturing materials (nails, sockets, and other hardware accessories) to retailers that contract for providing service. She has earned the trust of all of them. Her customers are scattered in the outer neighborhoods of the city; so she organizes the distribution according to routes. During these two years of work, she has not had high risks; so she feels very satisfied that work is calm with regular profits. In the future, she plans to buy her own car to improve her income. This is her thirteenth MFP loan, and she knows that the money will be very beneficial, so she promises to pay her dues promptly. Rosa has planned to invest the money requested on the conversion of the fuel tank of the car to one that will run on natural gas, to save on fuel, and thus hopes to continue progressing.

Translated from Spanish by Dina Bach, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Convert the fuel tank of the car to one that will run on natural gas

loans.name: Mti-Pesa Group

texts.en:
Amri K., age 32, is married and has a daughter of 3 years.  He has been a carpenter for 4 years now. He works from 7am to 6pm daily and he is able to make monthly profits of about $41.

This will be Amri’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loan to buy wood for his carpentry business and has paid this loan back successfully.  He hopes to receive a loan to buy a machine to drill and plane wood.

Amri will share this loan with his loan Group, Mti -Pesa, which totals 24 members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.
